awd_titl_txt: Cold atom mixtures of fermions and bosons on a lattice
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Physics Division and the Division of Materials Research contribute funds to this award. This award supports integrated theoretical research and education on systems of cold atoms near the absolute zero of temperature and trapped in laser light. The research is aimed to investigate new quantum mechanical states of matter that may be designed and engineered with mixtures of atoms and molecules at ultra low temperatures and to open new avenues for using ultra cold atom systems like a special kind of computer to simulate the correlated motion of electrons in materials and theories studied in high energy physics and quantum chemistry. 

With the progress in the ability to manipulate cold atoms and molecules and to control the interactions among them, the models that have been studied in materials research for their relevance to understanding complex materials that are promising for future technological applications may be engineered and tested. Even more importantly, new quantum many-body states will be sought, some that do not have a counterpart in materials or nanoscale systems. The PI will explore phenomena that emerge from the complex correlated motion that arise from interactions, dimensionality, and lattice geometry in these systems, as well as mixtures of particles with different quantum mechanical properties, for example some that in a sense behave like quanta of light mixed with others that behave like electrons, lead to the rich behavior of these quantum many-body systems. 

The PI will also continue her education and outreach activities that include training of graduate and undergraduate students in research and working with local K-12 schools and teachers through the Scientists in the Classroom Program. The Scientists in the Classroom Program is an outreach program that the PI started under prior NSF support and is supported by the UC Riverside Department of Physics and Astronomy and by the California Science Project. It provides a bridge between physics students and schools in the community, enriching the education of K-12 students and providing an important professional development opportunity for University of California Riverside students to improve their teaching, communication, and presentation skills. The PI and participants of the Scientists in the Classroom Program will share their passion for physics and the fascinating physics of ultra cold atoms and of emergent phenomena with college and K-12 students and the general public.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

The Physics Division and the Division of Materials Research contribute funds to this award. In the past few years, there has been remarkable experimental progress in the field of atomic, molecular and optical physics, including manipulation of ultra-cold atoms on optical lattices, and an unprecedented level of control and tunability of their interactions. In the vast landscape of possible microscopic interactions that can be tuned in cold atom systems, it is important to have systematic studies of phase diagrams and phase transitions, and to search for key physical principles that govern quantum many-body systems. This project investigates many-body effects in cold atom systems with a focus on mixtures of cold atoms and molecules. This research is integrated with education and outreach activities.

The objectives of this project are:

(1) To investigate cold atom systems with long-range interactions, proposing ways to engineer long-range interactions with boson-fermion and fermion-fermion mixtures, exploring dipolar quantum systems which have recently been realized and already have tunable long-range interactions built-in, and studying the long-range interaction coming from narrow Feshbach resonances and its effect in a many-body system.

(2) To investigate fermion-fermion mixtures, including SU(2) x SU(6) systems and fermions in mixed dimensions.

(3) To investigate cold atom systems in the strong coupling regime, including connections between gauge theories and lattice models in the strong coupling limit that can be created with cold atoms. It develops a new renormalization-group approach for repulsive fermions in the strong coupling limit.

(4) To explore renormalization-group approaches to study dynamical effects in cold atom systems.

The PI will also continue her education and outreach activities that include training of graduate and undergraduate students in research and working with local K-12 schools and teachers through the Scientists in the Classroom Program. The Scientists in the Classroom Program is an outreach program that the PI started under prior NSF support and is supported by the UC Riverside Department of Physics and Astronomy and by the California Science Project. It provides a bridge between physics students and schools in the community, enriching the education of K-12 students and providing an important professional development opportunity for University of California Riverside students to improve their teaching, communication, and presentation skills. The PI and participants of the Scientists in the Classroom Program will share their passion for physics and the fascinating physics of ultra cold atoms and of emergent phenomena with college and K-12 students and the general public.

por.por_cntn:
The remarkable experimental advances in the field of Atomic, Molecular and Optical physics has led to the ability of trapping cold atoms in place and of controlling and tuning their interactions. With the experimental manipulation of cold atoms on optical lattices and control of interactions, models that have been studied in Condensed Matter Physics for their relevance to various complex materials may be engineered and tested. More importantly, new quantum many-body states that do not have a counterpart in solid state systems have been obtained, and others are yet to be explored. Cold atoms can also be used as quantum simulators for lattice gauge theory models of interest to high energy physics. We have explored and exploited the vast landscape of possible microscopic interactions that can be tuned in cold atom systems to elucidate key physical principles that govern quantum many-body fermion and boson systems and the design realizable quantum simulators, as highlighted here.


Quantum materials: Recent experiments demonstrated the ability to create cold atom mixtures where different atomic species are confined to move in different dimensions. We have shown how, for fermions on a two-dimensional lattice, a triplet pairing BCS state can be created with realistic critical temperatures by exploiting the long-range interactions mediated by atoms of another species moving in the surrounding three-dimensional space. This may open new directions for studying Majorana fermions and spin textures with cold atoms on optical lattices.


The Joule expansion (free expansion) of a gas plays an important role in classical thermodynamics. We investigated it for non-integrable quantum systems that contain bosons or fermions in one-dimensional lattices. The properties of the time-evolved density matrix, the diagonal ensemble density matrix and the corresponding canonical ensemble density matrix with an effective temperature determined by the total energy conservation were studied. We proposed that the Joule expansion can be used as a way to dynamically create negative temperature states, which have known interesting and unusual behavior.


Quantum simulation: We proposed ways in which cold atoms on optical lattices can be used to quantum simulate models studied in lattice gauge theory. Specifically, we formulated a way to quantum simulate the O(2) model and the Abelian-Higgs model in (1+1) dimensions using one- dimensional Bose Hubbard models that can be created experimentally with cold atoms on optical lattices. We calculated the von Neumann and Rényi entanglement entropies of the O(2) model with a chemical potential. We demonstrated that current experiments with cold bosonic atoms trapped in one-dimensional optical lattices can be used to verify detailed predictions of conformal field theory, such as the Calabrese-Cardy scaling form, and estimate the value of the central charge. The Polyakov loop is an observable studied in lattice gauge theory that plays an important role in finite-temperature studies and in deconfinement transitions. We calculated and compared the Polyakov loop, in the Lagrangian and Hamiltonian formulations, and obtained universal functions relating the mass gap, the gauge coupling, and the spatial size, which are invariant under the deformation of the temporal lattice spacing. We provided a specific candidate system for building this simulator based on cold atoms in multi-leg ladders interacting via Rydberg-dressed interactions. This provide a possible path for the analog quantum simulation of lattice gauge theories with atoms in optical lattices.


Quantum information: We investigated the entanglement entropy of low-dimensional quantum systems. We developed a technique, based on conformal field theory predictions, open-boundary DMRG wave-functions, and scaling analysis of the entanglement entropy, to locate critical points and extract universal quantities for one-dimensional quantum Hamiltonians.

The paradigm of Schrödinger's cat illustrates how quantum states preclude the assignment of definite properties to a macroscopic object. We developed a method to investigate the indefiniteness of macroscopic cat states that can be carried out with currently available cold atom technology. The method we proposed uses the observation of a statistical distribution to demonstrate the macroscopic distinction between dead and alive states, and uses the determination of the interferometric sensitivity (Fisher information) to detect the indefiniteness. We showed that combining the two observations can provide information about the structure of the quantum state without the need for full quantum state tomography, and proposed a measure of the indefiniteness based on this structure.


Other broader impacts: Our investigations of new regimes of quantum many-body systems and our proposals for utilizing interacting Hamiltonians that can be created with cold atoms as quantum simulators have impact in high energy physics, condensed matter physics, atomic molecular and optical physics, and quantum information. Other broader impacts include training of graduate students and outreach to K-12 local schools through the Scientists in the Classroom Project and the UCR Summer Physics Academy.
